title.rendered: Indoor Plants and Pet Safety Guide

content.rendered:
The indoor plants are the dynamic beauty of any home. Significantly, it would not be wrong to give them the epithet of ‘jewels of homes’. Along with giving a refreshing look to a home, the indoor plants are also beneficial for health concerns.

Perquisites of having Indoor Plants in your Home

The profuse perquisites of having indoor plants are the reason for their utmost demand in the home decoration. In general, greenery is always celebrated for its curative and pacifying impact on the havoc nerves. Having a therapeutic sway, homeowners frequently prefer to ornament their homes with this soothing beauty. Indoor plants can invoke a charismatic look as well as healthiness to your home.

How Indoor Plants can be toxic to Cats and Dogs?

With plenty of their benefits, the indoor plants might be oozing tension in a case you are a dog person or cat person. Having a home full of indoor plants and a pet at the same time can be dangerous for the health of pets while harmless to human beings. The situation can create tension for the owner. As it is examined that indoor plants can be toxic for dogs and cats if they consume them. The toxic effect of intaking may vary, it can be mild, severe, or even fatal.

Is there any possibility of the Co-existence of Pets and Indoor Plants?

Needless to say, it is quite difficult to always keep an eye on pets with the determination of keeping them away from eating indoor plants. Therefore, before growing plants inside the home, it is very essential to take precautionary steps for the security of your pets. To cope with this concern, we have formed a pet safety guide for relieving your stress. Delightfully, it is no more a matter of strain until and unless the essential precautionary measures have been taken. The co-existence of pets and plants is now possible without compromising on the safety of pets. As per the veterinarians, the coexistence of plants and pets is only possible, you just need to know which plants are toxic for pets. Consequently, grow non-toxic and pet-friendly plants. Fortunately, we have a vast variety of plants that are not threatening to pets yet beautiful. Below is the list of non-toxic plants that are recommended by veterinarians and harmless for pets.

List of non-toxic plants that you can easily co-exist with cats and dogs without posing a menace to their health or life.

  • African Violet: African Violet is one of the top choices of veterinarians because of the harmlessness of this plan to your furry friends. African violet will brighten up the overcasting vestige of the home.
  • Bromeliad: Bromeliads are best to place or hang in windows they need profusion of open air. This pet-friendly plant will not hurt your pet and give an enthralling look to your windows.

 

    • African Violet: 

Asparagus fern is the aficionado of the Liliaceae family. With its blowout of feathers and often embellishment of white tiny flowers, it can be used to engross the minute detailing of your home.

  • Polka dot plants: 

Polka dot plants are one of the most common indoor pet-friendly plants due to their flamboyant foliar pageants.

 

    • Friendship Plant:

With the banquet of knottily patterned soft leaves, a friendship plant is considered to be the best for reinforcing the appealing look of your home with no threat to your pets.

  • Areca Palm:

If you are yearning to make your home eye-catching, this lush green beauty is the perfect contingency to boom the look of your home décor.  Areca palm will enhance the look of your home without threatening the life of your four-leg friends.

 

  • Mosaic Plant: The mosaic plant can credibly make your backyard or pool mesmeric with the hypnotically beautiful diamond-shaped leaves.

However, trivial negligence while picking indoor plants for the home can be dangerous for your pets. A small act of keenness can protect your pets and help to embellish your home with fresh green plants. Besides, it is better to consult a  veterinarian for an expert’s opinion.
